job_title: Postsoctoral Research Fellow in Seattle, WA
pros: Great resources for postdoctoral research. Opportunities to work for and with the greatest scientific minds in the world. Plenty of funding for research.
cons: Administration creates red tape and road blocks that make it difficult to complete research in a timely manner. Administrative leaders are not proactive or forward thinking. They create problems that force department to make tough decisions. Given the cost of living in Seattle, they notoriously underpay researchers and claim there is “no money”. Administration promotes the progressive research and cultural actions by UW, but they do not act like the world class leaders advertised on the website or in news releases. A researcher may think that University administration is “too far” in the structural tree to affect their work, but the culture trickles down and can make working in a research lab difficult. University of Washington may be a top tier, international research institution, but if you want a job as a postdoc or research staff, go somewhere else. Despite having many great mentors and research opportunities, it’s not worth it here, and you can be just as successful and happier elsewhere.

review_title: Good starting experience for professional researchers
pros: Good networking opportunities (both laterally/amongst colleages and at the levels of your direct supervisors/managers) Unionized Very diverse and inclusive work environment (could be more or less so depending on your specific lab/department/etc.)
cons: Very few opportunities for contract reviews, promotions, salary raises (outside of having generous managers/supervisors) Poor networking opportunities (for much higher level researchers than yourself and higher level management beyond your direct supervisor) Salary ranges are much lower than private industry counterparts in similar fields (For international applicants): Well known to have difficulties pushing through visa process for professional research staff Senior/high-level management have no clue about the day-to-day issues faced by most professional staff (outside their own lab groups if they have those)

pros: Interesting people, beautiful setting, mostly good working conditions.
cons: It's a faculty governed institution. Most faculty don't have training in managing anything except their own research, so its too easy to get placed under someone who is not good at the job they've decided they can do with no training. Very rigid caste system for non-academic employees. Few advancement opportunities.

review_title: Role really depends on the dept and colleagues
pros: It does depend on which department you are in and the hierarchal structure that might or might not exist there.
cons: The building itself is old and could use upgrades but there are no funds to do so.

review_title: Good job for students, flexible and well paid
pros: -Good job for students (looks very good on resume and you learn a lot of relevant skills) -Good pay (esp if you stay longer as you get a raise every year if I recall) -Management actually cares about you and your well-being (at least when I was there, I believe there has been a switch in management) -You can develop many skills and if you proactively learn, it can lead to a lot of opportunities -Very understanding of student schedules -There is a good training process in place. For me it was a bit of a learning curve as I was an out-of-department hire, but if you had worked as an EVS or Info desk employee, the role of SBM would be a more natural progression. In the end, I would highly recommend this job to a student who is proactively seeking growth opportunities and excels at multitasking, handling a lot of responsibilities, and managing priorities.
cons: -SAFETY :( When I had worked there, it was only 1 SBM who closed at night (12:00 AM). This was super dangerous and no student is qualified to essentially be "Security" and lock down the entire building alone. I had been chased and harassed by many less-than-friendly guests who were trying to stay overnight in the building. I think things have changed now, but that was definitely a safety risk. -You have a lot of responsibility, more than an average student job. This isn't an easy job, and you will feel drained after a shift (if there are a lot of events and issues that night).

job_title: Program Coordinator II in Seattle, WA
pros: The work is mainly service-driven thus not that stressful working towards departmental goals.
cons:
This university just gets progressively more toxic in how it imposes its politics on employees who work here. It's like either you acknowledge the Duwamish tribe in your courses or shut up about it. You can easily tell where certain colleagues lie on the liberal spectrum by their decision to put their pronouns in their signature - not because any gender clarification is needed but because it gives them a sense of pride like they're really doing something to support marginalized groups with that pronoun in their signature. 
I was happy working here until my self-righteous white supervisor and colleagues decided they were experts on fighting racism and everyone else needed to "do the work" with the formation of a completely ineffective DEI team and hiring an external consulting group of equally like-minded people. Saying this as a person of color to all the other persons of color who start working here: Avoid your department's DEI committee like the plague. Trust me, you will not be there to "make a difference". You're sole purpose is to validate the whites and assure them that they know and understand everything about how to support people of color. Though it would be better for them to take a course on human psychology instead of grabbing their woke pitchforks and jabbing it at others like that's going to really do something for fighting racism.

pros: Health insurance, including free dental.
cons: Like working at any large university, your experience will absolutely depend on your individual unit. In my experience at UW the university was unwilling to pay people what they were worth, or hire enough people to keep a unit functionally running. UW pays a lot of lip-service to work/life balance and wellness and supporting employees' mental health, but while I was expected to provide this understanding and flexibility to employees on my team (and was happy to do so as their manager) the same was not offered to me from my supervisors. I went 7 months without a single check-in from my direct supervisor (over 2 entire quarters) during the height of the pandemic. Working at UW was the worst professional experience of my life. If offered a job here, investigate your unit's work culture and future supervisors/partners/co-workers carefully.

pros: UW has all of the scientific resources (instrumentation) and expertise you'll need for your project. Professors/labs are highly collaborative. The scientists are fun, not cut-throat, laid-back but efficient. UW offers good benefits, especially healthcare.
cons: Everything else could use improvement. UW has one of the largest overheads (taking grant money to pay administrators), and you don't see any trickle down effects. UW does not adequately invest in their infrastructure- including both buildings/instrumentation and researchers (who are the ones bringing in all of the money). I have personally witnessed multi-million dollar instruments be ruined by the decrepit status of buildings with no concern from higher-ups. I and many others have not received promised raises for long periods of time (approaching a year in some cases), largely due to administrative inaction/inflexibility. UW does not appear to care about retaining research talent in any manner. The pandemic has exacerbated the existing cracks in UW's structure, and parts are starting to crumble- the outlook is not good.

pros: I absolutely love my job at MISL. They are exceptional, always encouraging me to pursue my passions, then supporting me in completing my goals. My manager has been so understanding and positive whenever I have made mistakes. The work environment carries this positivity. All the faculty are very helpful and understanding when starting new research projects that I have little knowledge about. I have made very good friends in my coworkers. The lab itself is beautifully clean and well organized. Beautiful views of ocean and lots of private working rooms. MISL ignited my passion for STEM and helped me find focus in my studies. Whatever I do in my career post undergrad, I will owe mostly to MISL. I cannot say enough good things.
cons: I like my job so much that I find it hard to prioritize school. The first few months of training were quite challenging.

pros: Benefits, flexible schedule and time off. I got lucky in that my office is good about me having a flexible schedule and doesn’t micromanage, but it depends on where you end up in the university. cons:

review_title: UW is an inhuman place for staff
job_title: Digital Imaging Specialist in Seattle, WA
pros: Great students, beautiful place to work
cons:
• Sexual misconduct against students gets repeatedly swept under the rug. This allows the offenders to go get a tenured gig somewhere else instead of being out of a job like they should. I wouldn't allow my kids to go there for this reason alone.

• Faculty in my former dept let international student get off with only apologizing when being caught stealing and plagiarizing another students work. Justification was so that they don't get sent back to their home country, coincidentally shared by professor. 

• Faculty spend obscene amounts of money on tech that get's locked away and rarely used. Rules for use of student tech funds are knowingly violated.

• Faculty consistently bully staff with impunity. I've had other friends be forced to quit jobs they love because of out of control faculty.

• Higher up in HR concurred that the UW is an inhuman place to work and that because of it's size it's very difficult to change, but they're working on it. 

• There are tools in place to "fight" these things, but it's weighted heavily against staff in the burden of proof.

review_title: Not worth it, unless you have a partner who can financially support your household
pros:
-Decent work/life balance
-Low pressure work environment
-Central location for easy commuting
cons:
-Terrible pay, and you're lucky to get a 2% annual increase. Any time I've mentioned wanting to discuss a raise or promotion over the last four years they say "we don't have the money" and it's end of discussion. A manager even told me I should look elsewhere if I wanted more responsibilities and higher pay.
-No career development opportunities or guidance (once you're in a position they want to keep you there forever). You have to fight for opportunities and you won't be rewarded for going above and beyond in your role.
-Mixed messages around work formats - for months we've been told hybrid and remote work was going to be supported, but there's a constant push to get people back on campus with reasons being "so leadership sees you" and "for the camaraderie."
-The U District isn't a very safe place, even though the community and UW are working on making it better. We regularly get alerts that there are armed robberies, thefts, and assaults, at all times of the day, and rarely hear about anyone being caught.
-For the last year there has been a lot of talk about DEI, but it's a very white workplace and it isn't clear what they are doing to make it more welcoming to non-white staff and faculty.
-Lack of communication across units/schools within UW - no one ever seems to know what anyone else is doing. Part of this is because it's a very siloed environment, but everyone knows that and just accepts it instead of trying to figure out how to make improvements.

job_title: Student Program Advisor in Tacoma, WA
pros:
- There always seem to be professional development opportunities (seminars, certificate trainings) available to staff. Staff Association offers scholarships for opportunities offered outside campus.
- Understanding, “people-centered” supervisors.
- High level of autonomy and trust in professional staff to pursue self-directed projects they believe will improve campus culture.
cons:
- High cultural expectation to take on “other duties as assigned,” even if they don’t relate to the core job duties or take time away from core job duties.
- Does not seem to offer comprehensive manager/HR training or centralized resource guide — this would be especially useful for new professionals with student employees. There ARE piecemeal trainings available, but some of the useful ones are only offered rarely, or need to be requested on demand.
- While the Tacoma and Bothell campuses have since been designated by the state legislature as their own institutions, they were founded as satellite extensions, and residue of that earlier dynamic feels as if it remains present in some interactions with the Seattle campus. We’re in a strange in-between space in which we’re no longer a satellite extension, but not are we as separate as two UC schools.

pros: Working as a communications assistant in the office of the academic program I was studying in meant that I had the chance to brush elbows with the faculty and keep on their radar. The pay was reasonably good (three dollars an hour above minimum wage in Seattle). The work was largely routine and easy, with a few fun challenges thrown in on occasion. I liked my supervisor, which I think probably makes all the difference.
cons: There was no designated office space for myself or the other part-time student worker, so we were just working in part of the office of one of the permanent staffers. Luckily we were all laid back and got along, but I could see this being a problem if the three people working in a single little office grated on one another. Part of the work also involved coordinating with students and alumni of the program to get quotes and content for the program's website and social media, which only became an issue when not enough people responded. That's not so much a problem with the job/employer itself as just a frustrating part of the work, but it could be tiresome.

If you have wide skills, you'll be consulting on many projects, even in other departments campus-wide. cons: Pay is almost exactly 50% of that found in the non-academic engineering world. Also, the UW is a state university, with all that implies. UW has many wonderful benefits including good health care benefits, decent leave policies, and good retirement plans. As a state agency, some employees are also eligible to participate in state pensions.

One of the things that keeps employees at UW is that higher education draws people who care about the mission and students. My team is incredibly supportive even when times have been difficult for our unit.

review_title: Good place to work, especially if you're interested in part time school.
pros:
The benefits and the flexibility really pay off when working for the university.  One of the best reasons to be there is to pursue a degree of some sort in your spare time; the university offers a (qualified) tuition exemption program for staff that can give you 6 credit hours per term in any course that has space available.  Most workplaces tend to be flexible when it comes to schooling for their employees.

The health benefits are good, and the workplaces are generally fairly low stress.  You get to go home at 5 as well, and telecommuting once a week is an option.
cons:
The salary.  I tend to make, by some estimates, 40K less than what I could be making at a comparable private sector job.  Money is not the most important thing in life, but in places like Seattle, it makes things like home ownership extremely difficult.
In my current position, as well, there is no track for advancement.  I really enjoy working with the folks that I do, but promotions and raises (other than annual cost of living bumps) just don't happen.
